objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to explore how large language models (LLMs) can be combined with evolutionary computation techniques to automatically discover optimization algorithms for designing photonic structures.
objective.evidence: We study how large language models can be used in combination with evolutionary computation techniques to automatically discover optimization algorithms for the design of photonic structures.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the gap in domain-specific guidance for LLM-driven algorithm discovery in photonic problems, which previously relied on generic task prompts and limited evolutionary strategies.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Original LLaMEA prompts lacked domain-specific guidance, which can lead to suboptimal algorithm designs for photonic problems.

answer: Introduction of structured task prompts enriched with photonics-specific problem descriptions and algorithmic insights.
Systematic evaluation of five new evolutionary strategy configurations to balance exploration-exploitation trade-offs.
evidence: To overcome these limitations, we introduce structured task prompts enriched with photonics-specific problem descriptions and algorithmic insights.
Furthermore, we systematically evaluate five new evolutionary strategy configurations-(1,5), (1+5), (2,10), (2+10), and (5+5)-to balance exploration-exploitation trade-offs.

inspirational_papers.answer:
- van Stein and Bäck (2024) LLaMEA framework inspired the extension to real-world photonic problems. (Methodological precursors)
- Bennet et al. (2020) Their photonics and ARCoating testbeds were used for problem simulation. (Experimental baselines)
inspirational_papers.evidence: In this work, we extend the capabilities of the Large Language Model Evolutionary Algorithm (LLaMEA) framework [33] to deal with real-world photonic problems... We apply LLaMEA to real-world problems published by P. Bennet et al. to automatically discover and implement photonic structure optimization algorithms [2, 33].

steps.step: Real-world problem simulation using PyMoosh and migration to IOHexperimenter platform.
steps.input: Problems defined by P. Bennet et al. and PyMoosh toolkit.
steps.output: Simulated photonic optimization problems for benchmarking.
steps.evidence: Building on PyMoosh, P. Bennet et al. have developed a testbed for defining and solving photonic optimization problems [2]. Based on their work, we migrate the following problems to the IOHexperimenter platform [5].

steps.step: Enhanced task prompt design with problem description and algorithmic insight.
steps.input: Domain-specific knowledge and meta-prompts to GPT-4.
steps.evidence: To improve LLaMEA’s ability to address domain-specific problems, we have added two key sections to the original task prompt: Problem Description and Algorithmic Insight.

steps.step: Automatic generation of algorithms using LLaMEA.
steps.input: Structured task prompts and evolutionary strategies.
steps.output: Generated optimization algorithms for photonic problems.
steps.evidence: We chose LLaMEA as the algorithm discovery method in our experiments for the following reasons: Targeting continuous optimization problems... Reliable performance.

tools.evidence: Python-based Multilayer Optics Optimization and Simulation Hub (PyMoosh) is a numerical toolkit for calculating the optical properties of multilayer structures [17].

tools.name: IOHexperimenter
tools.description: Platform for defining and solving photonic optimization problems.
tools.evidence: Based on their work, we migrate the following problems to the IOHexperimenter platform [5].

evaluation_metrics.purpose: Measures the area over the convergence curve.
evaluation_metrics.application: Used as feedback to the LLM for algorithm improvement.
evaluation_metrics.evidence: We use the metric suggested by LLaMEA, AOCC, as a feedback to the LLM.

areas.name: Applied Sciences & Engineering
areas.description: The paper focuses on optimizing photonic structures, which is a key area in engineering.
areas.evidence: Optimization of photonic structures plays a key role in the advancement of technologies in various fields such as telecommunication, solar energy, and materials science.

performance_summary.summary: The algorithms generated by LLaMEA achieve advanced performance on real-world problems, matching or surpassing state-of-the-art methods like DE and CMA-ES.
performance_summary.evidence: In complex photonic optimization tasks, LLM generates algorithms that can match or even surpass state-of-the-art methods (e.g., DE and CMA-ES) with performance comparable to human-designed heuristics.

baselines.name: Differential Evolution (DE)
baselines.description: A commonly used algorithm for photonic structure optimization.
baselines.evidence: In addition, five algorithms commonly used in the field of photonic structure optimization are added to the benchmark to provide a performance comparison, including DE [7].

baselines.name: Covariance Matrix Adaptation Evolution Strategy (CMA-ES)
baselines.description: A state-of-the-art optimization method for continuous problems.
baselines.evidence: In benchmarking continuous problems, it produces algorithms that are comparable to or better than state-of-the-art optimization methods such as the covariance matrix adaptation evolution strategy (CMA-ES).
